text: Surgoinsville June 23 1908
My Dear Mother,
tank said he telegraphed you the day Uncle Will died.
re drove me doun to the house the day he was buried. He
toned so calm å peaceful, just as if he were asleep. He told
titre the last time he was in the graveyard where he wanted
ire grave å asked Mr. Mccutchan to conduct the service.
mie pall bearers were old soldiers å before closing the grave
mey all put a flower in the grave. Nr. Mccutchan, De Miller
seusin Wiley Young, old Mr. Cox, Mr. Buck Phipps were the only
es i knew. They were all so old å feeble some younger men
nad to take it before they got to the grave. He was buried
i a very handsome casket & they had hot house flowers from
moxville on sallie's fixed by a florist. One very large wreath
vich Father on it. I suppose the children all got that.
sot sick at the grave & had to leave & did not see it after
chey were on it. I had not been well for several days & the
services were so long & the heat made me all trembly & sick
at the stomach. I got all right after I came home. We wouldnt
have known Uncle Will was dead if Jim Forgey hadnt stopped in
out of the rain & you would never have known that I was any
Kin to Frank or any of them. Miss Ida Smith, Rich s sweetheart
seemed to have charge of the house. They had thirty to eat
dinner. Alice said she did not see what on earth people came
there to eat for. They sang the same songs they sang at Aunt
Sallie's funeral. Everything was so pretty at Stony Point.
The trees & flowers Uncle Will had planted & looked after.
Stony Point will never be the same again. The children &
grandchildren almost filled one side of the church. None of
Charlie's family except Charlie-- very thin. He walked with
Billy. He looked so pitiful. Jim nor any of her family were
there. I heard when I first came up here that Clint was in
some trouble about selling whiskey & that Jim was sick. She
didnt come to Aunt Sallie s funeral. I suppose they are poor
g it may be the boys are at work. Frank hired a carriage.
Bob Armstrong & Mary rode in Sam's buggy & Sara went in the
garriage with De Miller. Sam looked so bad & the perspiration
mas just pouring off of him. He got into the Burem boy's buggy
e rode part of the way. The procession reached from the house
ta the church. This country will surely miss those two old
moople. They havent any children that can begin to take their
piages. De Miller looks old & shakey & so does Cousin Wiley
gaung. Mr. Will Waterson died about ten days ago. Annie is
iek nearly every day but she must be stronger than I think
e must have wonderful will power. She stood that trip as
all as I did & it certainly was an awful one. We started
to the church about two à when we got home it was past siy a
e left before the others did. I was strongly tempted to pack
my trunk å leave for home all last week. Think I would but
didnt think I could stand it. I want to see you. Sam wrote
last week wanting me to come over there. Said Sara was sick
